summary: A man and his son encounter a legendary demon while searching for hidden treasure in 19th-century India.

reviews.content: Only one word to say for this Movie.... A Masterpiece
How in the world is this supposed to be good? It's not terrible, but it's def weak in every department.
How come this movie has lesser IMDb rating than Kantara? This movie is a milestone and hasn't got the recognition it deserves. It's just epic!
Story doesn't have much of any creativity, visuals and cinematography is just too good. The writer of this film nicely portrays his hate towards his superiors, uppercast brahmins.

Very much underrated and under-appreciated film, one of the best film of its genre (horror/thriller). Lesson to learn: greed is bad.

This movie really knows how to create an atmosphere. Gripping story that felt very real despite the fact it's based on myths. I chose to watch it in a dark cottage in the middle of nowhere, a decision I regretted during some of the scarier parts of the movie!

I loved this movie the it's best movie in Bollywood and will always be it's not filled with songs or any bulls shits it has the best vfx Bollywood can ever imagine using and it should be recognized by all Indians and it should be realesed again in cinema because it gotta earn what this movies deserves but Indians didn't give it what it deserved they throw money like blind to famous celebrities movie even those movies are bad as hell but they overlook this masterpiece that has ever created in Bollywood this type of movie will not be seen in Bollywood for ages untill tumBaad 2 comes

I would say that this is by far, a near perfect movie in every aspect and one of my favourite films made so far by the people from Indian cinema !! It is a masterpiece and indeed deserves more respect and appreciation !!

Tumbbad scares the hell out of seasoned horror flick fans. So much so that you want to see it again. Captures history without an editorial-like perspective or narrative, but beckons you to judge it for yourself. Extremely mature film making that it does not emply even a single jump cut or audio effect to inject fear. It soaks you in slowly with its aura. It's unlike anything you have ever watched.

I seriously feel sorry for anyone who thinks this is ‘scary.' One of the reviewers referred to it as "scary as hell" and I'm convinced we watched different movies. 
It's interesting as a morality tale (which is what it is, despite all of the terms you're seeing tossed around to describe it) but it's rather predictable -and gets very, very boring about 40 minutes in and doesn't really improve in terms of suspense or scares or chills. 
If you think of it as a traditional morality tale you'll probably enjoy it. If you think you're watching a horror movie, the 40 minute mark will set you straight that you're watching a very mediocre movie that is wrapped up around mythology. And there's nothing scary about mythology even though story specifics can be shocking. 
Not horror. Not scary. Not even close. Mediocre but not horrible. Definitely not a waste of time if you're looking for something with a moral. 
"Scary as hell"…LOL…same fools who think mayonnaise is spicy think this movie is "scary."
Very nice movie, Which has deserved OSCAR.

Would you believe me if I tell you the budget of this film is just 5 crores (nearly $700k)? Before you let that fact sink in, would you believe me if I also tell you that this is the director's first ever film? Rahi Anil Barve - remember this name. You might need to speak it when someone asks you who your favourite Bollywood director is. This film was made for 6 years. Keep reading, I will tell you why it took so long.

Tumbbad is set in the village of the same name in Maharashtra. The story is set during the colonial period, and also some of it just after the independence. Though the village exists in real, it is nothing like what has been described in the film. According to the film the village has been cursed for writing the name of Hastar, a demon son of a Goddess who gave birth to 160 million gods. Because of the curse it is always raining in Tumbbad. Since the budget of this film was so low, the filming was only done during monsoon season when it was actually raining in the village. That's how low the budget of the film is - they couldn't even afford fake rain so they had to wait for 6 years to complete the filming.

In spite of the low budget, it does not give the feeling of being cheap at all. In fact if I didn't know better, I'd think this is a very expensive film. The actors aren't popular, but I don't see where the problem is over there. How many of us knew the names of all the actors from Baahubali? Still we watched it, right? So I'd think this is also a regional film. The acting is phenomenal. The horror scenes absolutely give me the creeps. It's perfect in every sense. Even the ending is left on an ambiguous note, enough to leave a shrill down anyone's spine. The posters of this film are also very good, and it's a shame to say that the worst one has been used over here. Look up for the other posters on Google Images.

The reason why Tumbbad failed to cross a huge commercial mark is because it wasn't advertised at all. If I hadn't read an answer on Quora that said it should have been sent to the Oscars instead of Gully Boy, I'd have never even known about its existence. There was literally no talk of it. Sure it has a low budget for making the film, but that doesn't mean they shouldn't spend in the marketing at all. It was so awesome, I for one would have definitely seen it if I had heard about it before. Also the only way to watch it now is through Prime, which will show you this film only if you type the correct spelling in the search box. It's a shame that you can't watch this film unless you know specifically what you're looking for.

I really admire the dedication of the director to make this film. He clearly knew this film wasn't going to be earning those big bucks, yet he continued to make it. This is what happens when you have directors who treat their work not as products but rather as works of art. I really aspire to be a filmmaker of that type. This film will be a very big lesson to me. I wish Rahi Anil Barve a very successful and prosperous career in the future.
Amazing. Story , music, acting , excellent ! There is a lesson too this movie teaches.
Best of Indian cinema. Must watch. Brilliant cinematography.

Rahi Anil Barve and Anand Gandhi has skillfully combined the elements of a folklore, horror, thriller and darker aspects of human psychology into this cult movie of bollywood. Anand Gandhi has yet again proved his directorial prowess in indian cinema. Powerful perfomance by its caste and gripping background score compels you to live its unsettling atmosphere.
    Just like Snowpiercer and Pan's Labyrinth this movie stays with you for a long time. I was eagerly waiting for this movie after watching its trailer and it didn't disappointed me from any aspect.

Last but not least, the voice over of grandmother was phenomenal. Another thing that people talk a lot about how Tumbbad is failed to be a horror flim although those claustrophobic scenes were petrifying for certain audiences. I think that's what they wanted us to see something out of the box nothing like conventional horror. Tumbbad will not give you sudden shocks like conjuring or other horror movies but will take you to a different venture of weirdness like Eraserhead.

A film split into chapters, flows with perfect pace beautifully shot, subtly acted, wonderfully edited that beautifully illustrates the three stages of human life with a moral on greed running through its core.
Itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s dark, brooding and engaging from the first frame with stunning cinematography and story telling pulling on familiar rules to horror but doing it an refreshing way ï¿ 1/2 1/2you must always feed grandmaï¿ 1/2 1/2ï¿ 1/2Â? 

The films middle section takes our lead character to adult life where it is a rich mans world. Pacing wise a bold move to side step from the horror built up in the first third but it is clever because it sets perfectly the empty heart of our corrupted lead neither hero or villain but a family man competing in a world at war over greed.  

Chapter three is beware what we teach our children taking the film full circle with clever choices visually by the director that lead you thinking you know the ending and takes you once more down the action horror whole. 

The whole film is a planted seed that feels refreshing and with imagery that will stay with you long after the credits roll.
Interesting and has different kind of story line. too good . love to see such movies waiting for part2

I posted the wrong star rating. before. I wanted to post 5 stars. I loved Tumbbad! It's a dark fantasy Indian movie. I watched it twice.  Wish I could give it more stars! Excellent movie.  Please don't expect Tumbbad to be a jump-scare horror film it's not meant to be that, neither did it ever purport to be. Tumbbad is based on a Hindi fictional mythological type story set in Maharashtra in the 1918 to 1948 period post India independence.. The story spans three generations. The screenplay,  brilliant acting and lavish cinematography and story have created a small masterpiece.. 
No expense was spared making this riveting film also a feast for the senses. The film is a chilling fantasy fable of greed across generations. The story traces the fortunes of a poor boy from a  small family who returns to his home, a bleak poverty stricken, cursed place, where a demon was once revered where it will always rain, called Tumbbad. The trailer doesn't do the film justice. The actual  story is chilling and it's  just brilliant.
 There are a few 'professional ' reviewers out there who have incorrectly  tried to compared Tumbbad to a typical Hollywood horror that they may have seen which it is not, neither ever purported to nor tries to be. Tumbbad is way better;  in a league and class  of its own.  I think Tumbbad will achieve cult status. Amazing Amazing Amazing! I  loved it!

Very creative, very very unconventional. Movie keeps you puzzled with what next. The relationships in the family and the time line chosen for the events are all simply amazing.

Really enjoyed this film.  Its not often that an Indian horror intrigues me (not being racist, Im African/Indian).  The story is very unique and deals with and old folklore.  The plot involves sympathy, greed, sacrifice, maturation, etc.  Its through the mistakes of the dad that the child learns whats important.  This film had a few scares and very dark, interesting story.  The scares were actually pretty fun!  The acting was great from everyone involved; the entire sold their characters very well.  The cinematography was amazing, ie the beautiful/terrifying locations and their usage of dark/light.  I would definitely recommend this to horror fans.

'Tumbbad' is an incredibly crafted genre-defining flick and if you love watching movies, do make sure that you watch it before the theaters end its run.

I happened to watch Tumbbad last night and I must say, it is an incredible experience, very unlike anything coming from Bollywood. It's so refreshing to see a flick that cares about creative vision, intricate set designs, cinematography, and sound design. There's no big-budget star cast, no larger-than-life glittering sets, and no over the top music and dance sequences. Yet, Tumbbad manages to present a really skillful and perfect artwork on the screen that offers an absolutely fascinating visual and audible experience. It's a "must-watch in the theaters only" kind of film.

I know a lot of people who're skeptical about it, thinking it's a horror film. But there's a stark difference between the typical horror stuff with jump scares that we're used to seeing, and what Tumbbad delivers. It's a 'Fantasy Horror' film, but one that's based on a powerful storyline with a primary theme of 'greed'. It won't leave you looking over your shoulder once you step out of the theatre and around the corners at home, it just isn't your exorcism and "bhoot-preyt" kind of horror. What it is, is thrilling, gripping, and surreal.

Lastly, one of my favorite parts of the film is its background score by Jesper Kyd. Tumbbad is scored by Jesper Kyd - the same man behind the popular games like the Hitman series, Assassin's Creed series, Borderlands series, Darksiders II and State of Decay. His music is what brings the film to life in the theater.
Well directed and nerve racking movie.

An astonishing movie!

It isn't your usual horror movie, which is why it brings such a refreshing change, particularly in context of Bollywood, where nothing like this has ever been tried before. It is a movie, that needs to be seen, appreciated, and more importantly, encouraged in Bollywood, where script almost always takes a backseat (Though there are movies coming up that are breaking this trend). Add to that a music that really keeps you at the edge of the seat, this is an experience that needs to be witnessed!

Quick takeaway? Tumbbad needs to be seen by more people! Watch it to witness an experience that stays with you, long after you have left the theater!

Indian folk tales have been oddly ignored by the Hindi film industry despite their endless cinematic potential. Tumbbad shows us what we might have been missing, and in unforgettable fashion. It is terrifying, surprising and utterly unique. Certainly one of the best movies of the year, quite possibly among the best horror films I've watched. I would even go far enough to say it's one the most striking pieces of cinema that India has ever produced. Watch in a theatre!
